Two cents on Wall street separating fact he is he's been critical of the central bank before President Trump is criticizing the fed again as too aggressive after yesterday's sell off blamed mainly on rising interest
A in some ways the mark as having a fit about this one of them is on the short end of the curve they're beginning to raise interest rates right the economy's thought it was generally being stronger they're looking at the data they're looking at the inflation living with the labor markets and saying it's time to raise interest rates
Another point I'll mentioned by the way of the reasons why they should be doing this is because we're going to need some ammunition at the fed is going to be an interventionist and not just let the the markets dictate the policy you're going to need some ammunition later when we do find ourselves looking down the barrel of another recession
And right now the few areas in their quiver because they have been nearly packed emergency interest rate territory for quite some time
And the other thing to do so they're raising rates right the second thing they're doing this for a significant change
Is that they're shrinking the balance sheet or the Federal Reserve they got to about four and a half trillion dollars on their balance sheet and different forms of debt today on on the ... to the Federal Reserve there's over Seventeen and a half trillion dollars in global central banks
So that's a lot of money printing that is taking place and now there we used to call that quantitative easing you remember ... when we were talking about the ... money printing and the buying a bond they called quantitative easing one or two or three times and loosening of the monetary policy in a very comedy the stance as well as providing liquidity to the marketplace
And the markets ran up largely on that activity and news and it's sort of help pull us out initially out of the financial crisis is one of the components
In addition to that it's helped risky assets real estate or equity markets
Appreciate because of all that liquidity it's needing to go somewhere
Near the second thing that they're doing that is shrinking their balance sheet now so if you look at a chart that shows the increasing the balance sheet to increase looks like a hockey stick
The early going straight out before and a half trillion and now it's beginning to slowly roll off and how they're doing is not necessarily going out actively selling bonds and their balance sheet but they're allowing the bonds that are maturing
To mature and roll off and not purchasing new ones and so that again to slowly begins to unwind the balance sheet but that's quantitative tightening
So we've gone through now eight nine years of ... a combination of policy by central banks primarily the Federal Reserve here in this case and they have now changed that regime from emergency territory interest rates and quantitative easing
To raising of interest rates and qualitative tightening so you just have to understand that this is going to have some implications to the overall market we have been talking about this regime change them when they started doing it and ah December of Fifteen but really in two thousand sixteen
And we've seen a lot of good things including the equity markets charts looking favorable
But a lot of that's beginning to break down in fact we talk about it in this week's newsletter
So it brings me to that head to the website register have not done so already we talk about some of this regime change what's taking place of the equity markets and how they affect you and your money headed website S T wealth dot com you'll see the SPA money out [noise]
